[[Caliciviridae]] |genus = [[Norovirus]] |species = 'Norwalk virus' }}



'Norwalk virus' is known as winter vomiting virus, which was originally named
after Norwalk, Ohio, in the United States, where an outbreak of acute viral
gastroenteritis occurred among children at Bronson Elementary School in
November 1968.

Viruses are classified into family, genus, and species by the International
Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV), {{Cite document
|url=http://www.ictvonline.org/virusTaxonomy.asp |title=Virus Taxonomy: 2011
Release (current) |publisher= International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses |postscript= }} and Norwalk virus is the only
species of the genus [[Norovirus]], which belongs to the family
[[Caliciviridae]]. Formerly, Norwalk virus was included in the genus "Norwalk-
like virus" between 1999 and 2002, {{cite journal |author= Pringle CR
|title= Virus Taxonomy at the XIth International Congress of Virology, Sydney,
Australia, 1999 |journal=Archives of Virology |volume=144 |issue=10
|pages=2065â2070 |year=1999 |pmid=10550679 |doi=
10.1007/s007050050728}} {{cite journal |author= Pringle CR |title=
Virus Taxonomy â 1999. The universal system of virus taxonomy, updated to
include the new proposals ratified by the International Committee on Taxonomy of
Viruses during 1998 |journal=Archives of Virology |volume=144 |issue=2
|pages=421â429 |year=1999 |pmid=10470265 |doi= 10.1007/s007050050515 }}
and the "Norwalk-like virus" was replaced with Norovirus on the 8th Report of
the ICTV {{Cite document
|url=http://ictvonline.org/virusTaxonomy.asp?version=2007 |title=Virus Taxonomy:
2005 Release (8th Report) |publisher= International Committee on Taxonomy of
Viruses |postscript= }} in
response to the approval of the new name of Norovirus at the 12th International
Congress of Virology in Paris (2002). {{cite journal |author= Mayo MA
|title= A summary of taxonomic changes recently approved by ICTV
|journal=Archives of Virology |volume=147 |issue=8 |pages=1655â1663 |year=2002
|pmid=12181683 |doi= 10.1007/s007050200039}} Because the genus Norovirus
has only one species {{cite book |editor= Andrew M.Q. King, Elliot
Lefkowitz, Michael J. Adams and Eric B. Carstens |doi=10.1016/B978-0-12-384684-6.00084-
7 |title=Virus Taxonomy: Ninth Report of the International Committee on Taxonomy
of Viruses |chapter=Family â Caliciviridae |publisher=Elsevier
|location=Amsterdam |year=2011 |pages=977â986 |isbn=978-0-12-384684-6}}
(Norwalk virus) as well as the fact the genus "Norwalk-like virus" was
officially replaced with the genus Norovirus, these often cause confusion on the
correct usage of the term Norovirus and that of Norwalk virus. Currently, the
term norovirus has been more frequently used in the media and by health
authorities.

In association with the circumstances, {{cite news
| title=Getting Rid of Norovirus work=The New York Times date=April 1, 2010
| accessdate=January 7, 2013 url=http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/04/01/getting-rid-of-
| norovirus/}} the ICTV received a request to rename the genus Norovirus
| in earlier 2011 because children in Japan and elsewhere who have the family
| name "Noro" may have the possibility of teasing or bullying from others. The
| ICTV circulated the concerns to many international virologists, including
| those who originally proposed the taxonomic name, and the concerns were
| extensively discussed. A press release
{{Cite document |title=Press release |publisher= International Committee on
Taxonomy of Viruses, Virology Division-IUMS |date=Sep 14, 2011 |postscript= }} and a newsletter {{Cite
document |title=2011 ICTV Newsletter #9, November 2011
|url=http://talk.ictvonline.org/files/ictv_documents/m/newsletters/4069.aspx
|publisher=International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses |date=November 14,
2011 |postscript= }} were
finally published by the ICTV in 2011, which strongly encourage the media,
national health authorities and the scientific community to use the virus name
"Norwalk virus", rather than the term "norovirus," when referring to outbreaks
of the disease. The ICTV regards the usage of the term "norovirus" as incorrect
when referring to outbreaks actually due to Norwalk virus because there is no
virus species called norovirus.
